questions.article:
The following text is from Jhumpa Lahiri's 2003 novel The Namesake. Gogol, a child, is at a beach in Massachusetts with his father.

He watches his father raise a kite within minutes into the wind, so high that Gogol must tip his head back in order to see, a rippling speck against the sky. The wind whips around their ears, turning their faces cold.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “tip” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Lean

options.name: B
options.content: Create

options.name: C
options.content: Pay

options.name: D
options.content: Teach

questions.correct: Lean

questions.article: The Chauvet Cave paintings—detailed paintings of animals found in what is now France and dating from 30,000-32,000 years ago—are thought of as art today, but how the people of the time understood the paintings is ______. They may have thought of the paintings as something akin to art in our modern sense, but it is entirely possible that they did not-we simply cannot say for certain.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: unknown

options.name: B
options.content: unalterable

options.name: C
options.content: unsurprising

options.name: D
options.content: uncontroversial

questions.correct: unknown

questions.article: Some ethicists challenge the concept of personal character, claiming that if it were meaningful, situational factors could not, as they clearly can, induce behavior contrary to that character. As Rachana Kamtekar observes, this argument is difficult to reconcile with our lay conception of character: we expect a person of helpful character to be frequently helpful, not ______ helpful.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: unfailingly

options.name: B
options.content: self-servingly

options.name: C
options.content: grudgingly

options.name: D
options.content: sporadically

questions.correct: unfailingly

questions.article: Some cities estimate where sidewalks are located using road maps, which is not very accurate. Maryam Hosseini and her team trained a computer program to identify sidewalks in aerial images of Manhattan and used it on images of Chicago. The program's performance was ______ to that of the road-map method: it more accurately identified sidewalks, and it even distinguished between concrete and brick.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: changed

options.name: B
options.content: supportive

options.name: C
options.content: similar

options.name: D
options.content: superior

questions.correct: superior

questions.article: Literary production in the period after the Mexican Revolution (which lasted from 1910-1920) was ______, with writers like Octavio Paz contributing to the outpouring of poetry, fiction, essays, and more. Unfortunately, this flood of interesting writing can divert scholarly attention from the fascinating work of nineteenth-century figures like Guillermo Prieto.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: occasional

options.name: B
options.content: inconsistent

options.name: C
options.content: disfavored

options.name: D
options.content: prolific

questions.correct: prolific

questions.article: When people think of dinosaurs with feathers, they typically think of winged dinosaurs, such as the four-winged Microraptor. However, many dinosaurs that didn't have wings also had feathers on their bodies. For instance, research indicates that the wingless, speedy Ornithomimus likely had feathers.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It explains the scientific debate about the finding discussed in the previous sentence.

options.name: B
options.content: It points out several weaknesses in the theory presented in the previous sentence.

options.name: C
options.content: It identifies the researchers who made the discovery mentioned in the previous sentence.

options.name: D
options.content: It provides a specific example of the dinosaurs described in the previous sentence.

questions.correct: It provides a specific example of the dinosaurs described in the previous sentence.

questions.article: Known for the albums E.S.P. and 'Round About Midnight, jazz trumpeter Miles Davis collaborated several times with pianist Gil Evans. Their 1958 adaptation of George Gershwin's opera Porgy and Bess bears little resemblance to the 1935 original. Davis and Evans felt no desire to please listeners expecting an exact duplication of the opera. They omitted parts, such as the aria “I Got Plenty of Nuthin'," and sometimes made only brief gestures toward Gershwin's melodies. But Davis and Evans's willingness to recompose Gershwin's work led to one of the most enduring albums in Davis's catalog.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To summarize the history of a long collaboration between two artists

options.name: B
options.content: To describe how two artists transformed another artist's work

options.name: C
options.content: To explain why works of art most likely to be praised by critics are those that defy tradition

options.name: D
options.content: To present reasons why one work of art should be considered superior to another

questions.correct: To describe how two artists transformed another artist's work

questions.article:
The following text is from Julia Alvarez's 2000 novel In the Name of Salomé. Salomé, a poet, is hosting guests in the front parlor of her family home, and Ramona is her sister. A salon is a social gathering for the exploration of intellectual ideas.

It was evening when the two men got up to leave. Tia Ana had already come into the room several times to see if these guests had departed yet. The front parlor had always been her special province, as she used it for her little school. Now, every evening, it turned into Salomé's salon, as Ramona called it, and it was never in order for its transformation back to a classroom the following morning.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the reference to the parlor as Tía Ana's "special province"?

options.name: A
options.content: It conveys that Tía Ana feels honored that her classroom is used for important events.

options.name: B
options.content: It characterizes the room as a place where Tía Ana can go to escape social pressures.

options.name: C
options.content: It reveals that Tía Ana feels as if Salomé has betrayed her trust by allowing guests into a space she considers her own.

options.name: D
options.content: It introduces an idea that helps explain Tía Ana's apparent eagerness for Salomé's guests to leave the space.

questions.correct: It introduces an idea that helps explain Tía Ana's apparent eagerness for Salomé's guests to leave the space.

questions.article: Dandelions are a kind of weed found in North America. Although dandelions are unwelcome in gardens and on farms, weeds like this do provide some benefits. For example, they can be helpful to pollinators.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Some weeds can be beneficial.

options.name: B
options.content: A variety of plants grow in North America.

options.name: C
options.content: Removing weeds is a pleasant task.

options.name: D
options.content: Some gardening techniques may increase weed growth.

questions.correct: Some weeds can be beneficial.

questions.article: Optimal foraging theory (OFT) holds that animals’ foraging behaviors reflect cost-benefit trade-offs that vary by species and with dynamic ecological circumstances. One such circumstance is lunar intensity, which Rodrigo A. Vásquez found to be negatively associated with foraging by olive grass mice but Deborah J. Curtis and colleagues found to be positively associated with foraging by mongoose lemurs. This discrepancy is explicable in terms of OFT: the lemurs' greater reliance on vision means that higher lunar intensity benefits them more than it benefits the mice.
questions.question: Information in the text best supports which statement about OFT?

options.name: A
options.content: It tends to allow for a better understanding of the benefits of ecological circumstances than the costs of those circumstances.

options.name: B
options.content: It can account for observations of different species responding differently to similar ecological circumstances.

options.name: C
options.content: It can explain why some species act in accordance with cost-benefit trade-offs and others do not.

options.name: D
options.content: It may be weakened by the finding that the costs and benefits associated with a particular ecological circumstance vary by species.

questions.correct: It can account for observations of different species responding differently to similar ecological circumstances.

questions.article: The nearly forty tribes located in Oklahoma, including the Choctaw Nation and the Seminole Nation, operate numerous businesses, employ tens of thousands of people, and generate billions of dollars in revenue. A student in an economics class is researching the tribes’ collective activity as a single industry, the student wants to compare that industry's role in Oklahoma in 2017 with the roles of other industries in the state. Looking at a table with information about three industries, the student finds that compared with the other two industries, tribal economic activity ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the comparison?

options.name: A
options.content: made the lowest total contribution by industry.

options.name: B
options.content: ranked highest in all three economic measures listed in the table.

options.name: C
options.content: made the highest average economic contribution per employee.

options.name: D
options.content: employed the same number of people as accommodation/food services.

questions.correct: made the highest average economic contribution per employee.

questions.article: The Age of Innocence is a 1920 novel by Edith Wharton set in 1870s New York City. In the novel, Newland Archer attends an opera. The narrator describes Newland's tendency to follow the social conventions dictated by other men of New York City society who are in the audience: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from The Age of Innocence best illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “Singly [the men around Newland] betrayed their inferiority; but grouped together they represented 'New York, and the habit of masculine solidarity made him accept their doctrine on all the issues called moral.”

options.name: B
options.content: “Newland Archer, leaning against the wall at the back of the club box [where his seat was], turned his eyes from the stage and scanned the opposite side of the house.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Newland Archer felt himself distinctly the superior of these chosen specimens of old New York gentility; he had probably read more, thought more, and even seen a good deal more of the world, than any other man of the number.”

options.name: D
options.content: “No expense had been spared on the setting, which was acknowledged to be very beautiful even by people who shared [Newland’s] acquaintance with the Opera houses of Paris and Vienna.”

questions.correct: “Singly [the men around Newland] betrayed their inferiority; but grouped together they represented 'New York, and the habit of masculine solidarity made him accept their doctrine on all the issues called moral.”

questions.article: One antipredator defense that the grey-headed lapwing uses to protect its nest and young chicks is called “broken-wing display.” This form of deceptive defense involves an adult bird pretending to be injured and unable to fly in order to distract an approaching predator. Broken-wing display has been documented in 285 bird species from 13 different avian orders. A student predicts that bird species with mean body masses greater than 150 grams do not use deceptive defenses because larger birds tend to be more effective than smaller birds at using aggressive defenses to protect nests from predators, making deceptive defenses unnecessary.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table that weaken the student's prediction?

options.name: A
options.content: The common ringed plover uses broken-wing display, but the pied-billed grebe does not.

options.name: B
options.content: The pied-billed grebe has a mean body mass of 409 grams and is known to perform broken-wing display.

options.name: C
options.content: The common snipe uses broken-wing display even though it is larger than the common ringed plover.

options.name: D
options.content: The common snipe and the common ringed plover both have a mean body mass under 150 grams and use broken-wing display.

questions.correct: The pied-billed grebe has a mean body mass of 409 grams and is known to perform broken-wing display.

questions.article: Describing adverbs “as damaging to a writer,” novelist Graham Greene is one of several authors and literary critics who have recommended minimizing the use of adverbs, especially those ending in -ly (e.g.,“obediently”), in works of fiction. To investigate the prevalence of -ly adverbs in novels, author and statistician Ben Blatt used natural language processing—machine learning technology that reads and interprets text—to calculate the rates at which these words occur in the novels of Ernest Hemingway, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954. Blatt concluded that in Hemingway's oeuvre, there is a negative correlation between -ly adverb proliferation and perceived literary merit.
questions.question: Which choice, if true, best supports the researcher's conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Whereas Hemingway's acclaimed novel The Sun Also Rises has one of the lowest -ly adverb rates among Hemingway's works,F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel The Great Gatsby has the lowest -ly adverb rate among Fitzgerald's novels.

options.name: B
options.content: Whereas Hemingway used on average 80 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words in the 10 novels of Hemingway's that Blatt investigated, Toni Morrison, winner of the 1993 Nobel Prize in Literature, used on average 76 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words in her novels.

options.name: C
options.content: In his celebrated novel A Farewell to Arms, Hemingway used 67 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words, whereas 67% of celebrated authors' novels that have fewer than 50 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words have been classified as great by critics.

options.name: D
options.content: In The Sun Also Rises, which is widely recognized as a literary masterpiece, Hemingway used 63 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words, whereas in his less-acclaimed novel True at First Light, Hemingway used 102 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words.

questions.correct: In The Sun Also Rises, which is widely recognized as a literary masterpiece, Hemingway used 63 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words, whereas in his less-acclaimed novel True at First Light, Hemingway used 102 -ly adverbs per 10,000 words.

questions.article: Scientists recently created a model to predict how increasing human activity will affect future mammal population sizes in US national forests. Unfortunately, when the model is applied to large forests, its predictions for large-mammal populations are too high, and when applied to small forests, its predictions for small-mammal populations are too high. Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest in Montana is a large forest, covering more than 3 million acres. If used to evaluate the effect of increasing human activity on this forest in ten years, the model would likely therefore ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: exaggerate the effect of increasing human activity on small mammals.

options.name: B
options.content: overestimate the actual population sizes of large mammals.

options.name: C
options.content: ignore the predator-prey relationships between large and small mammals.

options.name: D
options.content: reflect factors affecting large mammals other than increasing human activity.

questions.correct: overestimate the actual population sizes of large mammals.

questions.article: While the ancient Celts—Iron Age peoples who inhabited parts of western and central Europe—weren't a single unified group, their art often featured common elements. These included intricate patterns of interlocking spiral lines, which often held symbolic ______ of birds, horses, and other animals; and inlaid enamel accents.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: significance; depictions

options.name: B
options.content: significance, depictions

options.name: C
options.content: significance. Depictions

options.name: D
options.content: significance: depictions

questions.correct: significance; depictions

questions.article: Paramaribo, with a population of roughly 250,000 people, ______ home to an impressive 47 percent of Suriname's total population.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: is

options.name: B
options.content: are

options.name: C
options.content: are being

options.name: D
options.content: have been

questions.correct: is

questions.article: Robert B. Elliott was one of the nearly two thousand African Americans who won a public office during the Reconstruction era, the twelve-year period that followed the Civil War. A politician from South Carolina, ______
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Elliott was elected to the US House of Representatives in 1870 by his constituents.

options.name: B
options.content: 1870 was the year that Elliott was elected to the US House of Representatives by his constituents.

options.name: C
options.content: constituents of Elliott elected him to the US House of Representatives in 1870.

options.name: D
options.content: in 1870, his constituents elected Elliott to the US House of Representatives.

questions.correct: Elliott was elected to the US House of Representatives in 1870 by his constituents.

questions.article: The small celestial body known as 2060 Chiron is expected to have a relatively short lifetime in the outer solar system. Within just a few million years, 2060 Chiron is likely to migrate into the inner solar system or be destroyed, according to ______ trajectory.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: astronomers modeling of the object's

options.name: B
options.content: astronomers' modeling of the object's

options.name: C
options.content: astronomers modeling of the objects

options.name: D
options.content: astronomer's modeling of the object's

questions.correct: astronomers' modeling of the object's

questions.article: Paxillus panuoides fungi have a well-documented association with alder trees ______ is, symbiotic bonds between fungal hyphae and host tree roots—the organisms can create extensive nutrient exchange networks.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: trees, by forming mycorrhizal relations—that

options.name: B
options.content: trees by forming mycorrhizal relations, that

options.name: C
options.content: trees. By forming mycorrhizal relations—that

options.name: D
options.content: trees by forming mycorrhizal relations. That

questions.correct: trees. By forming mycorrhizal relations—that

questions.article: Patricia Hampl's essay on "terracette," a term referring to a series of terrace-like formations on a hillside, is just one of many essays included in Home Ground: A Guide to the American ______ by Barry Lopez and Debra Gwartney, the book celebrates the rich language used to describe the landscape of North America.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Landscape, edited

options.name: B
options.content: Landscape and edited

options.name: C
options.content: Landscape edited

options.name: D
options.content: Landscape. Edited

questions.correct: Landscape. Edited

questions.article: In 2005, notoriously shy American singer-songwriter Ray LaMontagne saw his life change with the success of his hit single “Trouble.” That year, he performed more than thirty live sets, including at Icahn Stadium in New York, United States, and Théâtre Outremont in Montreal, Canada; ______ he'd performed fewer than a dozen times in 2004.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: often,

options.name: B
options.content: additionally,

options.name: C
options.content: on the other hand,

options.name: D
options.content: similarly,

questions.correct: on the other hand,

questions.article: Unlike in Bolivia, where members of the national legislature are elected by a proportional representation system, legislators in Malaysia are elected via a single-member plurality voting system. ______ candidates in Malaysia are elected when they receive a plurality (i.e., greatest number) of votes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: In other words,

options.name: B
options.content: Meanwhile,

options.name: C
options.content: That being said,

options.name: D
options.content: Moreover,

questions.correct: In other words,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Morning Haiku (2010) is a book of poetry by African American poet Sonia Sanchez.
  • Each poem in the book is a sequence of haiku.
  • According to the book's publisher, Penguin Random House, the book “celebrates the gifts of life and mourns the deaths of revered African American figures.”
  • The poem “5 haiku (for Brother Damu)" is written as a sequence of five haiku.
  • The poem “15 haiku (for Toni Morrison)" is written as a sequence of fifteen haiku.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast the number of haiku in each poem. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The poems in Morning Haiku celebrate the lives or mourn the deaths of “revered African American figures," according to the book's publisher, Penguin Random House.

options.name: B
options.content: The poem “5 haiku (for Brother Damu)" consists of five haiku, whereas the poem “15 haiku (for Toni Morrison)" consists of fifteen.

options.name: C
options.content: While “5 haiku (for Brother Damu)" is about activist Brother Damu, “15 haiku (for Toni Morrison)" is about writer Toni Morrison.

options.name: D
options.content: Both “5 haiku (for Brother Damu)” and “15 haiku (for Toni Morrison)” can be found in Sanchez's 2010 collection Morning Haiku.

questions.correct: The poem “5 haiku (for Brother Damu)" consists of five haiku, whereas the poem “15 haiku (for Toni Morrison)" consists of fifteen.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Japanese Ministry of the Environment made a list of 100 soundscapes of Japan.
  • Each soundscape on the list was selected for its cultural significance to Japan.
  • The sound of the bell at Hikone Castle is on the list.
  • The sound of crickets on the banks of the Yodo River is on the list.
questions.question: The student wants to indicate that both soundscapes are on the list. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Each soundscape on the list, including the sound of the bell at Hikone Castle, was selected for its cultural significance to Japan.

options.name: B
options.content: The sound of crickets on the banks of the Yodo River is on the list.

options.name: C
options.content: Both the sound of the bell at Hikone Castle and the sound of crickets on the banks of the Yodo River are on the list.

options.name: D
options.content: The Japanese Ministry of the Environment made a list of 100 culturally significant soundscapes of Japan.

questions.correct: Both the sound of the bell at Hikone Castle and the sound of crickets on the banks of the Yodo River are on the list.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The United States has designated more than 500 areas National Wildlife Refuges (NWRs).
  • Some NWRs were established specifically to protect endangered species.
  • The St. Johns NWR is a 6,255-acre area in Florida, on the Atlantic coast.
  • It was established to protect the endangered dusky seaside sparrow.
  • The Bitter Creek NWR is a 14,054-acre area in California, on the Pacific coast.
  • It was established to protect the endangered California condor.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast the two NWRs. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Some NWRs were established specifically to protect endangered species such as the California condor.

options.name: B
options.content: Both the St. Johns NWR and the Bitter Creek NWR were established to protect endangered species.

options.name: C
options.content: While the St. Johns NWR is in Florida, on the Atlantic coast, the Bitter Creek NWR is in California, on the Pacific coast.

options.name: D
options.content: The US has designated more than 500 areas NWRs, including the St. Johns NWR in Florida.

questions.correct: While the St. Johns NWR is in Florida, on the Atlantic coast, the Bitter Creek NWR is in California, on the Pacific coast.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A supercontinent is a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth's continents.
  • Over time, continents merge together to form supercontinents, which then break apart.
  • This process is believed to take hundreds of millions of years and is known as the supercontinent cycle.
  • Kenorland and Rodinia were supercontinents.
  • Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago.
  • Rodinia formed about 1.1 billion years ago.
questions.question: The student wants to specify when Kenorland formed. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Long ago, the Earth was home to supercontinents like Kenorland and Rodinia.

options.name: B
options.content: The supercontinent Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago.

options.name: C
options.content: Over hundreds of millions of years, the supercontinent cycle results in supercontinents forming and breaking apart.

options.name: D
options.content: Kenorland was a supercontinent, a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth's continents.

questions.correct: The supercontinent Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago.
